hierarchy.lvl3: C4 The data in JTRAIN2 come from a job training experiment conducted for low-income men during 1976–1977; see Lalonde (1986).

hierarchy.lvl1: The Nature of Econometricd and Economic Data
hierarchy.lvl3: C4 The data in JTRAIN2 come from a job training experiment conducted for low-income men during 1976–1977; see Lalonde (1986).

records.content:
wooldridge.data('jtrain2', description=True)

df4 = wooldridge.data('jtrain2')

(i) Use the indicator variable train to determine the fraction of men receiving job training.

df4['train'].value_counts()

(df4['train'] == 1).mean()

185  men recieved the training representing 41.6\%

(ii) The variable re78 is earnings from 1978, measured in thousands of 1982 dollars. Find the
averages of re78 for the sample of men receiving job training and the sample not receiving job
training. Is the difference economically large?

df4['re78'].groupby(df4['train']).mean().round(3)

Men who recieved the training had average earnings of 6,349 while men who did not recieve the training had an average of 4,555

train_0 = df4['re78'].groupby(df4['train']).mean()[0]
train_1 = df4['re78'].groupby(df4['train']).mean()[1]

train_0, train_1

(train_1 - train_0) / train_0

Those who trained has an earnings increase of 40\% which is very large

hierarchy.lvl1: The Nature of Econometricd and Economic Data
hierarchy.lvl4: (iii) The variable unem78 is an indicator of whether a man is unemployed or not in 1978. What fraction of the men who received job training are unemployed? What about for men who did not receive job training? Comment on the difference.
hierarchy.lvl3: C4 The data in JTRAIN2 come from a job training experiment conducted for low-income men during 1976–1977; see Lalonde (1986).

hierarchy.lvl1: The Nature of Econometricd and Economic Data
hierarchy.lvl4: (iii) The variable unem78 is an indicator of whether a man is unemployed or not in 1978. What fraction of the men who received job training are unemployed? What about for men who did not receive job training? Comment on the difference.
hierarchy.lvl3: C4 The data in JTRAIN2 come from a job training experiment conducted for low-income men during 1976–1977; see Lalonde (1986).

records.content:
df4['unem78'].groupby(df4['train']).value_counts()

df4['unem78'].groupby(df4['train']).mean().round(3)

24.3\% of those who trained were unemployed, while 35.4\% of those who did noy train were unemployed. The difference in percentages seems large.

hierarchy.lvl1: The Nature of Econometricd and Economic Data
hierarchy.lvl4: From parts (ii) and (iii), does it appear that the job training program was effective? What would make our conclusions more convincing?
hierarchy.lvl3: C4 The data in JTRAIN2 come from a job training experiment conducted for low-income men during 1976–1977; see Lalonde (1986).

hierarchy.lvl1: The Nature of Econometricd and Economic Data
hierarchy.lvl4: From parts (ii) and (iii), does it appear that the job training program was effective? What would make our conclusions more convincing?
hierarchy.lvl3: C4 The data in JTRAIN2 come from a job training experiment conducted for low-income men during 1976–1977; see Lalonde (1986).

records.content:
The difference in earnings and unemployment is large indicating that training had a positive effect.
We need to statistically test the difference to know if its significant or due to random error

import pandas as pd
import numpy as np
import wooldridge
import statsmodels.formula.api as smf
import seaborn as sns
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

wooldridge.data()

ceosal1 = wooldridge.data('ceosal1')
wage1 = wooldridge.data('wage1')
vote1 = wooldridge.data('vote1')
meap93 = wooldridge.data('meap93')
jtrain2 = wooldridge.data('jtrain2')

hierarchy.lvl3: 2.1 Soybean Yield and Fertilizer
2.1 Soybean Yield and Fertilizer

records.content:
yield = \beta_0 + \beta_1 \, fertilizer + u

\beta_1 is ceteris paribus effect of fertilizer on yieldu contains omitted factors\Delta yield = \beta_1 \Delta fertilizer

hierarchy.lvl3: 2.2 A Simple Wage Equation
2.2 A Simple Wage Equation

records.content:
wage = \beta_0 + \beta_1 \, educ + u

\beta_1 measures change of wage associated with extra year of education, ceteris paribus

hierarchy.lvl3: 2.3 CEO Salary and Return on Equity
2.3 CEO Salary and Return on Equity

records.content:
wooldridge.data('ceosal1', description= True)

model03 = smf.ols('salary ~ roe', data = ceosal1).fit()
model03.params, model03.nobs

Salary is \beta_0 = $963,191 if return on equity is 0 [salary is measured in thousands]

roe is defined of net income as a percentage of common equityIf return on equity increases by one percentage point, salary will increase by $18,500

if roe=30, salary is expected to be (963.191 + 18.501(30)) * 1000 = 1,518,221

hierarchy.lvl3: 2.4 Wage and Education
2.4 Wage and Education

records.content:
wooldridge.data('wage1', description = True)

model04 = smf.ols('wage~educ', data=wage1).fit()
model04.params, model04.nobs

wage1['educ'].plot(kind = 'hist')

A person with no education is predicted to have an hourly wage of $-0.9. We got this result because the regression extrapolated

One more year of education is expected to increase predicted wage by $0.54

hierarchy.lvl3: 2.5 Voting Outcomes and Campaign Expenditures
2.5 Voting Outcomes and Campaign Expenditures

records.content:
wooldridge.data('vote1', description = True)

model05 = smf.ols('voteA ~ shareA', data = vote1).fit()
model05.params, model05.nobs

voteA and shareA are both percentagesone more percentage point change in shareA results in almost half percentage point increase of total vote

hierarchy.lvl3: 2.6 CEO Salary and Return on Equity
2.6 CEO Salary and Return on Equity

records.content:
df = wooldridge.data('ceosal1')
model06 = smf.ols('salary ~ roe', data = df).fit()

df['salary_hat'] = model06.fittedvalues
df['u'] = model06.resid
df[['roe', 'salary', 'salary_hat', 'u']].head(10)

int(df['u'].sum())

The \beta's are chosen to make sum of residuals = 0

hierarchy.lvl3: 2.7 Wage and Education
2.7 Wage and Education

records.content:
model07 = smf.ols('wage~educ', data=wage1).fit()
model07.params, model07.nobs

round(wage1['educ'].mean(),2), round(wage1['wage'].mean(),2)

new_data = pd.DataFrame({'educ': [12.56]})
model07.predict(new_data)

Rergerssion equation must pass through the mean points

hierarchy.lvl3: 2.8 CEO Salary and Return on Equity
2.8 CEO Salary and Return on Equity

records.content:
model08 = smf.ols('salary ~ roe', data = ceosal1).fit()
model08.rsquared

Firm return on equity explains 1.3% of the total variation in salary

hierarchy.lvl3: 2.9 Voting Outcomes and Campaign Expenditures
2.9 Voting Outcomes and Campaign Expenditures

records.content:
model09 = smf.ols('voteA ~ shareA', data = vote1).fit()
model09.rsquared

Share of campaign expenditures explains 85% of the variation in the election outcome

hierarchy.lvl3: 2.10 A log Wage Equation
2.10 A log Wage Equation

records.content:
model010 = smf.ols('np.log(wage)~educ', data=wage1).fit()
model010.params, model010.nobs, model010.rsquared

For every year of education, wage increases by 0.083 * 100 = 8.3\%

Note: adding log allowed to get constant percentage change interpretation

hierarchy.lvl3: 2.11 CEO Salary and Firm Sales
2.11 CEO Salary and Firm Sales

records.content:
model011 = smf.ols('np.log(salary) ~ np.log(sales)', data = ceosal1).fit()
model011.params

A 1% increase in firm sales increases CEO salary by about 0.257% [elasticity model]

hierarchy.lvl3: 2.12 Student Math Performance and the School Lunch Program
2.12 Student Math Performance and the School Lunch Program

records.content:
wooldridge.data('meap93', description = True)

model012 = smf.ols('math10 ~ lnchprg', data = meap93).fit()
model012.params

If student eligibility in lunch program increases by 10 percentage points, his math results falls by 3.2 percentage points

Note: nonsensical data, which shows that error term is correlated with the independent variable

hierarchy.lvl3: 2.13 Heteroskedasticity in a Wage Equation
2.13 Heteroskedasticity in a Wage Equation

records.content:
sns.lmplot(x='educ', y='wage', data=wage1, ci=None, line_kws={'color': 'red'})


plt.title('Wage vs. Education (Check for Heteroscedasticity)')
plt.xlabel('Years of Education')
plt.ylabel('Wage')
plt.show()

as years of education increases, variability in wage increases

hierarchy.lvl3: 2.14 Evaluating a Job Training Program
2.14 Evaluating a Job Training Program

records.content:
wooldridge.data('jtrain2', description = True)

model014 = smf.ols('re78 ~ train', data = jtrain2).fit()
model014.params, model014.rsquared

Workers who participated in the program earned $1790 more than those who did not, OLS assumptions are met due to random assignment

R^2 = 1.8\% shows that var(u) > var(y)

hierarchy.lvl3: C1 The data in 401K
C1 The data in 401K

records.content:
are a subset of data analyzed by Papke (1995) to study the relationship between participation in a 401(k) pension plan and the generosity of the plan.

The variable prate is the percentage of eligible workers with an active account; this is the variable we would like to explain.

The measure of generosity is the plan match rate, mrate. This variable gives the average amount the firm
contributes to each worker’s plan for each $1 contribution by the worker.

For example, if mrate = 0.50, then a $1 contribution by the worker is matched by a 50¢ contribution by the firm

wooldridge.data('401k', description=True)

df = wooldridge.data('401k')
df.head()

hierarchy.lvl4: i. Find the average participation rate and the average match rate in the sample of plans
hierarchy.lvl3: C1 The data in 401K

hierarchy.lvl4: i. Find the average participation rate and the average match rate in the sample of plans
hierarchy.lvl3: C1 The data in 401K

records.content:
df['prate'].mean(), df['mrate'].mean()

The average prate is 87.36 and average mrate is 0.73

hierarchy.lvl4: (II) Now, estimate the simple regression equation and report the results along with the sample size and R-squared.
hierarchy.lvl3: C1 The data in 401K

hierarchy.lvl4: (II) Now, estimate the simple regression equation and report the results along with the sample size and R-squared.
hierarchy.lvl3: C1 The data in 401K

records.content:
model = smf.ols(formula='prate ~ mrate', data = df).fit()

summary_df = pd.DataFrame({
    'term': model.params.index,
    'coefficient': model.params.values
})
summary_df['nobs'] = model.nobs
summary_df['rsquared'] = model.rsquared

summary_df

The intercept is 83.07, \beta is 5.86, n = 1534, R^2 = 0.75

hierarchy.lvl4: (iii) Interpret the intercept in your equation. Interpret the coefficient on mrate.
hierarchy.lvl3: C1 The data in 401K

hierarchy.lvl4: (iii) Interpret the intercept in your equation. Interpret the coefficient on mrate.
hierarchy.lvl3: C1 The data in 401K

records.content:
intercept = 83.75:- if mrate is zero, predicted participation rate is 83.05
mrate = 5.86:- one dollar increase in mrate will cause prate to increase by 5.86 (given the prate range allows this increase)

hierarchy.lvl4: (iv) Find the predicted prate when mrate = 3.5. Is this a reasonable prediction? Explain what is happening here
hierarchy.lvl3: C1 The data in 401K

hierarchy.lvl4: (iv) Find the predicted prate when mrate = 3.5. Is this a reasonable prediction? Explain what is happening here
hierarchy.lvl3: C1 The data in 401K

records.content:
new_data = pd.DataFrame({'mrate': [3.50]})
model.predict(new_data)

model.params['Intercept'] + model.params['mrate'] * 3.5

if mrate = 3.5, prate = 103.5 which isn’t possible because prate is bounded by range 0 to 100

hierarchy.lvl4: (v) How much of the variation in prate is explained by mrate? Is this a lot in your opinion?
hierarchy.lvl3: C1 The data in 401K

hierarchy.lvl4: (v) How much of the variation in prate is explained by mrate? Is this a lot in your opinion?
hierarchy.lvl3: C1 The data in 401K

records.content:
model.rsquared * 100

The model explains 7.5% from the variation in prate, indicating the inlfuence of other factors on prate

hierarchy.lvl3: The data set in CEOSAL2
The data set in CEOSAL2

records.content:
contains information on chief executive officers for U.S. corporations. The
variable salary is annual compensation, in thousands of dollars, and ceoten is prior number of years as company CEO

df.head()

import pandas as pd
import numpy as np
import wooldridge
import statsmodels.formula.api as smf

def summarize_model(model):
    """
    Returns a summary table with parameters, number of observations, and R-squared.

    Parameters:
        model: A fitted statsmodels regression result (e.g., OLS, Logit).

    Returns:
        pd.DataFrame: Summary table.
    """
    params = model.params
    summary_df = pd.DataFrame({
        'Parameter': list(params.index) + ['Number of Observations', 'R-squared'],
        'Estimate': list(params.values) + [int(model.nobs), model.rsquared]
    })
    return summary_df


wooldridge.data()

records.content: Yes, negative correlation. As income increases, personal care and education will also increase, resulting in fewer ciggarates

hierarchy.lvl4: (iii) Now, estimate the equation with and without faminc, using the data in BWGHT. Report the results in equation form, including the sample size and R-squared. Discuss your results, focusing on whether adding faminc substantially changes the estimated effect of cigs on bwght
hierarchy.lvl3: C1 A problem of interest to health officials (and others)

hierarchy.lvl4: (iii) Now, estimate the equation with and without faminc, using the data in BWGHT. Report the results in equation form, including the sample size and R-squared. Discuss your results, focusing on whether adding faminc substantially changes the estimated effect of cigs on bwght
hierarchy.lvl3: C1 A problem of interest to health officials (and others)

records.content:
wooldridge.data("bwght", description=True)

df = wooldridge.data("bwght")
df.head()

model1 = smf.ols(formula="bwght ~ cigs", data=df).fit()
model1.params, model1.nobs, model1.rsquared

model2 = smf.ols(formula="bwght ~ faminc + cigs", data=df).fit()
model2.params, model2.nobs, model2.rsquared

df["faminc"].corr(df["cigs"])

The correlation between faminc and cigs is weakly negative. When faminc is omitted, its positive effect on birth weight is absorbed into the cigs coefficient. Since faminc and cigs are negatively correlated, this leads to downward (negative) bias, making the effect of cigs appear slighly more harmful than it actually is.

hierarchy.lvl3: C4 Use the data in ATTEND for this exercise

hierarchy.lvl4: (ii) Estimate the model
hierarchy.lvl3: C4 Use the data in ATTEND for this exercise

records.content:
atndrte = \beta_0 + \beta_1 \, priGPA + \beta_2 \, ACT + u

and write the results in equation form. Interpret the intercept. Does it have a useful meaning?

model = smf.ols("atndrte ~ priGPA + ACT", data=df).fit()
model.params, model.nobs, model.rsquared

atndrte = 75.7 + 17.3 \, priGPA - 1.7 \, ACT \\
n = 680 \qquad R^2 = 0.29

The intercept indicates that a student with a prior GPA of zero and an ACT score of zero is predicted to have an average attendance rate of 75.7%. However, this estimate is not reliable, as it is the result of extrapolation beyond the range of the observed data—no students in the sample have both a zero GPA and a zero ACT score.

hierarchy.lvl4: (iii) Discuss the estimated slope coefficients. Are there any surprises?
hierarchy.lvl3: C4 Use the data in ATTEND for this exercise

hierarchy.lvl4: (iii) Discuss the estimated slope coefficients. Are there any surprises?
hierarchy.lvl3: C4 Use the data in ATTEND for this exercise

records.content:
df["priGPA"].corr(df["ACT"])

A one point increase in pri GPA increases attendace rate by 17.3 percentage points, holding ACT fixed.A one point increase in ACT score decreases attendace rate by 1.7 percentage points, holding prior GPA fixed. The negative relation may reflect that people with high ACT scores believe they can pass the lectures

df.loc[
    (df["priGPA"].sub(3.65).abs() <= tolerance) & (df["ACT"].sub(20).abs() <= tolerance)
]

A student with prior GPA of 3.65 and ACT score of 20 is exptected to have 104% attendance rate.Since that attendance rate is bounded between zero and 100%, we predict 100% insteadThe actual student with this data has participation rate of 87.5%
